qas.question: Why does the collector voltage drop in grounded-emitter transistor circuits?

answers.text: reduced resistance from collector to emitter

qas.question: What would happen if the voltage difference from collector and emitter were zero?

answers.text: the collector current would be limited only by the load resistance (light bulb) and the supply voltage

qas.question: What is the term for a zero difference between collector and emitter?
Why is the term saturation named as such?

answers.text: current is flowing from collector to emitter freely

qas.question: What position is the switch in when saturated?
What causes reduced resistance from collector to emitter?
What changes the most in a grounded-emitter transistor circuit?
What is the load resistance in a light bulb?
What changes the amount of supply voltage?

context: In a grounded-emitter transistor circuit, such as the light-switch circuit shown, as <b7_0>the base voltage<b7_0/> rises, the emitter and collector currents rise exponentially. <b9_0>The collector voltage<b9_0/> drops because of <a0_0>reduced resistance from collector to emitter<a0_0/>. If the voltage difference between the collector and emitter were zero (or <b8_0>near zero<b8_0/>), <a1_0>the collector current would be limited only by the load resistance (light bulb) and the supply voltage<a1_0/>. This is called <a2_0>saturation<a2_0/> because <a3_0>current is <b6_0>flowing from collector to emitter<b6_0/> freely<a3_0/>. When saturated, <b5_0>the switch<b5_0/> is said to be <a4_0>on<a4_0/>.
